title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions to address disparities in polling place availability. The Voting Rights Act is amended to recognize tribal identification documents as valid for voting purposes. The Attorney General has the authority to take legal actions, including against States, in the name of the United States. The Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents for voting. The Attorney General can take legal actions, including against States, to address disparities in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes. This includes increasing polling place availability. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over such actions, to be heard by a court of three judges. The Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal ID for voting. The Attorney General can address disparities in voting opportunities for Indian tribes. District courts have jurisdiction over such actions, heard by a court of three judges. An appeal can go to the Supreme Court. There is a presumption of denial of voting rights based on race or color. An aggrieved person can bring an action under section 4(f)(2) of the Voting Rights Act, with provisions applying to such action. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include protections for Indian reservations, requiring approval for activities like eliminating polling places or moving them further away. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations, requiring approval for actions like moving polling places further away or eliminating in-person voting on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions that diminish early voting opportunities or change voting dates on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for protecting Indian reservations by requiring approval for any activities that affect early voting opportunities or voting dates on reservations. Federal election oversight on Indian reservations is addressed in Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if complaints of voter rights violations are received from tribal organizations. SEC. 5 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding the termination of election observers. It specifies the conditions under which observers appointed under subsection (b) of section 8 will cease their duties. SEC. 6 provides definitions. SEC. 6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 provides definitions, including terms related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations as defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 7 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to update bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservation. SEC. 8 focuses on election observer transparency. SEC. 8 requires the Attorney General to publicly release reports of Federal election observers within 6 months. SEC. 9 mandates annual consultation with tribal organizations on voting issues for Indian tribes.
